Libet-alim, the second part of justice (XIV. 42), requires much cantion. Care should be taken not to barm either the recipients or other persons, as happened, for instance (43), in the confiscations and largesses of Sulla and Caesar. Again, liberality should be proportioned (44) to one’s ability, that other just claims may not be neglected. Thirdly (45, 46), regar-d ,should be had to the character of those who receive the bounty, and to our relations or obligations towards them.

Our benevolence is, above all, due to those (47) who love us most3 and, if in addition they have conferred benefits on us (48), we are still more bound to make a generous return.
